title: I'm honestly tired of this community
body:
I've tried my upmost with working with the LoL community and ignoring the levels of toxicity that occur. I even can openly point out that I have been toxic at times and I have suffered penalties for it. But for some reason, after I came off my hiatus this year and started playing League again, it seems that compared to last year, the community is 10x worse than it has ever been. Last year, it was mainly Normal PvP matches that had high levels of toxicity. But now no matter where you go, you will experience someone either mocking and insulting anyone they feel is doing wrong, targeting enemy players to grief them in an attempt to tilt them rather than just playing the game, or like my latest game, reconnect and disconnect for the first five minutes of the game. Rejoin the game at 20 minutes in and then feed.

I really just don't know what exactly to do with this game anymore. I'm so cemented into this game that I can't really stop playing even though I want to, but I'm honestly scared to go solo now in fear that I'm going to experience some level of toxicity. Literally, is Riot doing anything to fix this community, or are they just throwing chat restriction bans and then dicking around afterwards?

It can certainly feel that way many times, and is common when community size grows from a small "tight nit community" to larger at scale one. From my Rioter's perspective (and I suspect many other cases) there have been times that I've just been down right scared shitless to post or engage in discussion because the hate and yelling being a Rioter attracts. As you might imagine than, its discouraging to post places, which leads to the community feeling like they aren't heard and becoming frustrated, which leads to more hurt and more backlash, and more discouragement, cue the downward cycle. 

I also think that shouldn't stop Rioters (myself as the first example) from posting, nor are the frustrations, anger, and sadness felt by the community invalidated. I just think there is a better place to direct that energy than to just lash out. In the end its all our responsibilities as members of this community to contribute to the solution. Part of that solution, which I'd love to hear from y'all, is what you think all of us (Community & Rioters) can be doing. Would love to brainstorm ideas.

Again, I don't discount your anger and frustration and much of it I agree with. That being said it kind shuts me down of wanting to talk with you about things like this if I feel attacked :(.

We are not trying to attack you. If we were, we would downvote you. We are frustrated because Klain said things that are horrible and Riot has done things that are horrible. If Riot wants us to be less toxic they should start from themselves. 

I am not talking about you. I have read your comments in other posts and you seem to be a gentle and kind person. 

The fact is that I feel the same as Malefic Reality. I want toxicity in League to drop down, but it also is imposible to do if Riot doesn't get to fixing it. Community won't forgive the attack on its male part. Female part of the community is angry as well. They need to adress the problem, instead of avoiding it. They need to behave like adults.

The game has its problems as well:

Mid lane should actually be all about laning phase and people shouldn't be able to blow others up without hitting skillshots. More midlaners should be like Orianna. She is literally a perfect champion. I don't know who designed her, but he/she is a genius.

Jungling should be about smart pathing and decision making, but instead we have that oneshoting/stun locking meta. 

Top is not getting any love. The meta there is shifting from tanks to brusers and to tanks again. Tanks should be situational picks for top lane. Top is for brusers and they should be balanced a little bit more. As for now if they get buffed they will dominate and if they get nerfed they will be useless. Top is not balanced at all.

Adc is seriously weird now. Marksman are actually doing assassins job better than assassins. They are oneshoting people. Stormrazor should have never been introduced. ADC shouldn't oneshot people. They should do progressively more dmg with every aa hit or have to at least hit 5-6 aa to kill. Smart positioning and micro skills should be promoted here.

Support is not destroyed yet. They have got a lot of diversity and are actually the most balanced lane in LoL. It is actually quite fun to play. Just, Riot should stop with promoting dmg dealers on supp. Support, as the name suggests, should support the marksman. They should buy wards and healing items. Protect or heal or both.

I don't know why, but Riot makes questionable decisions since S7 and League is in bad state now. My solutions would be punishing people responsible for events that shouldn't have happened and starting hot fixing things more often. Everybody has noticed that MF is oneshoting, instead of being an adc. It doesn't feel fair at all. Mf is killing people on 1 aa and q. Also her ult can 100-0 the whole team. Hot fixing her would help.

Maybe Rengar should be nerfed or nerfing dark harvest and lethality would do something. Of course that are not the only changes that should happen. Lethality meta is just ... worse than tank meta. 

Fixing all of this would be hard. The essential part of League is jungle. It should be reversed to that beautiful jungle with benefits for smiting camps. A defensive or offensive ward for smiting wolfs was such a cool idea. Those buffs for killing minions were actually bad, but they could be changed into something creative.

Laning will always be about hitting minions and farming up. I actually don't know what could be improved there, except for towers. Towers are too weak. They fail to protect people. Actually even lvl 1 dives are possible.

I was trying to be as gentle as I could. If you don't agree I understand it. Every person's experience with the game differs. I apologise for making it so long and boring. Have a nice day.

I appreciate the thought out feedback. There's a lot to break down here (more than I'd want to type out), but I do think its worth discussing! I stream semi-frequently if you ever want to hop onto the channel discord to chat! I think it would be a super interesting discussion of how you think the game meta affects player behavior. I'm rather unconvinced either way, but I'll be the first to admit I haven't given the connection too much thought.

> I think it would be a super interesting discussion of how you think the game meta affects player behavior. I'm rather unconvinced either way, but I'll be the first to admit I haven't given the connection too much thought.

I'm not OP but I have some thoughts on this (as I'm sure a lot of people do). I don't think it's that a particular meta causes players to be toxic, exactly. It's just that League is, in the "best" metas, a game that is fraught with frustration already, and this has been talked about in the community extensively over the years. Here is why I think this season is different.

One of the greatest ways to breed frustration is to remove someone's agency, and many League players are very frustrated because they feel that they have very little or no agency in the game. I certainly feel this way. I can't tell you how many games this season have ended with me crying (yes, crying over a video game...) because I just felt so powerless to do anything to influence the game. You can probably guess that I like to play bot lane, mostly support and sometimes ADC. Earlier this season I felt pretty good, I was climbing at a high rate and felt like my actions were having an impact on the game. There were of course problems, such as level 3 ganks from junglers, and even though these things were annoying, I felt like I had the ability to deal with those setbacks. Now, if the enemy jungler ganks at level 2 or 3, and my jungler does not countergank, the lane is over; almost every gank requires me to blow all my summoner spells, and many times even that is not enough to survive, and the tower will not protect me. This feels awful, naturally. If my jungler can't get there fast enough, or my mid laner isn't a highly mobile champion, there isn't much to be done. 

But it's even worse than that. The jungler doesn't even have to gank my lane, but maybe they gank top. Not even camping, but just one single gank where they get a kill. Maybe the top laner made a mistake and deserved to die, but even this single gank can decide the fate of the whole game. The game is about a numbers advantage, and how you can surprise the enemy with your high damage and your numbers advantage. Like that infamous game where Fnatic hid in a bush next to baron pit and waited to surprise the enemy team. That's basically all of League right now. 

Oftentimes, whichever lane gets behind early is like an open wound for your team, and unless you can quickly react by taking an advantage elsewhere, you are left with this gaping hole that you can't fix, and it just keeps bleeding out until the game ends. I've had many, many games where we won the lane, even dominated the lane, but because top or mid received extra pressure from the enemy jungler and we weren't able to respond (or our jungler doesn't care to respond) we just lose anyway. I like to roam a lot as a support, even on enchanter supports that you don't expect to see roaming (for precisely that reason), but this season I feel that roaming has little impact on the outcome. I feel especially scared to leave my ADC at bot because they won't be able to survive a gank, even under our tower. I'm not confident in my ability to peel or negate damage as an enchanter anymore, and most people don't even play enchanters except for Nami. I personally feel that my playstyle is not welcome in League anymore; there is basically only one linear way to play the game, and it is not how I like to play. Again, this leaves me feeling alienated and lacking agency, and I've been playing the game for over five years, consistently reaching mid-high elo every season since season 4. Many ADC players have said this same thing: the champions they like, and the way they like to play, are not viable. 

My not very expert opinion is that the jungle has too much influence over the game. Not just the jungler, but the JUNGLE itself, including neutral and epic monsters, and plants too. The game is played too much around scuttle crab, dragon, rift herald, and baron. If the enemy has a more favorable early game comp and can secure early scuttles, herald, or god forbid an early infernal dragon, the game is pretty much done. Baron buff is basically a magic GG button; unless you are severely behind and achieve a steal, securing baron almost guarantees your victory without even much effort, even if you have not taken a single inhib turret yet. It's pretty frustrating as a player when the enemy team can secure baron and push in your base not even by grouping or attacking turrets, but just by standing in the general vicinity of a structure. They don't have to put themselves at risk from poke during a siege because of how weak turrets are, especially because of the cannon minion's ridiculous range and the overall tankiness of the wave. Nexus turrets are also a joke; if inhib turrets go down, the game is over, there is almost no point defending nexus turrets because, by this point in the game, almost everyone on their team can tank multiple tower shots without risk.

Some people might argue, isn't this the point of League? Taking objectives should result in a win. Well, yes and no. League is a game generally played out in multiple parts, which most refer to as (1) laning phase, (2) mid game, and (3) late game. However, in a meta that heavily favors the team which secures the most objectives as early as possible, there is almost no point in the laning phase or late game existing. The separate phases of the game lack balance, power is heavily skewed toward mid game, and the mid game comes much earlier than it used to. Does it matter if I killed my opponent five times in lane and got more CS, if their team just comes to kill me, takes an infernal or herald, and grabs a free turret or two? What's the point of even killing them 1v1? If you don't or can't roam to other lanes and kill everyone/take objectives, your lead is meaningless. Hell, it's even a greater advantage for the enemy when they get a ton of gold for killing you. This is where you get people saying they can't "carry" anymore. Well, you can carry, just not by winning your lane. The lane doesn't matter. 

Therefore, people who excelled at outplaying their opponent in lane feel that they have no power even if they won their lane, if they cannot get their team to press their advantage by taking objectives like herald or dragon (especially infernal). Likewise, champions who come online in late game don't get a chance to scale, as the game is entirely won in the mid game, and again only if you got those early epic monsters or scuttles. If the enemy team can gangbang you at bot or top early in the game, that means an early dragon or rift herald for them, and that almost always translates to a win in my experience. There are exceptions, of course, but this seems like the general trend. 

This overall sense of powerlessness and hopelessness breeds frustration and toxicity, especially if you don't understand what's happening or that your preferred playstyle just does not fit into this meta, and often people will shift blame onto their teammates for this. This is why you see those posts of people complaining about "inters" in their games; well, they're almost certainly not inting, the enemy team is probably just good at ganging up on them. Or, even worse (and this is something I see 100x more this season than previous seasons), they just give up. Enemy team got baron? We cannot defend against them. Enemy jungler is playing someone like Eve, Khazix, or Rengar, and they snowballed? There is nothing we can do. Enemy team took rift herald and got an early infernal? We won't be able to stop their push or compete with their damage. Maybe you've seen that phrase "go next" become popular recently; it's like the new "open mid," except people say it to their own team (and I hate it). People legit just give up in this meta, and honestly I find it hard to blame them, because most times there really is nothing you can do. By the time your top laner has died to a gank from the jungler and mid two times, the game is pretty much done, unless you were there to negate those ganks in the first place. Once a team gains that advantage from those early kills + objectives, it's incredibly hard to come back. 

**tl;dr** Many players who preferred to play the game a certain way are feeling alienated and powerless in the current meta, which heavily favors early game champions, especially early game junglers, who can create an insurmountable lead by early ganking. Neutral and epic monsters also have far too much impact on the game. Feeling hopeless and powerless breeds frustration, which often leads to toxicity, and a lack of understanding for how the current meta works can lead to players shifting blame onto their teammates, or just giving up completely as soon as anything goes wrong. Not saying this behavior is excusable or warranted, but perhaps that gives some perspective on the issue.

I think that's asking for a bit much in this situation. To me, it seems unreasonable to ask anyone to give a calm answer devoid of blame when you (or your company/ other members of your company) have wronged them. While I understand the policy for player-and-Riot communication is based on Riots doing it of their own will, with their own time; you are still representing the company as you do so. That comes with all the responsibility the entire company would have. And a company shouldn't be getting upset over their customers being upset about something the company did wrong. 

I personally do feel bad for you Rioters, you get so much shit trying to help the community. You do it because you recognize someone should, but because it's all optional no one else will. So it's always the nicest Rioters responding. It's just a shitty system. Riot _should_ have a team whose job it is to deal with these kind of things, but because of how things are, nice Rioters get cussed out when they're trying to help (because they're the only ones to talk to at Riot) and the community can never get communication.

I would also like to say that I want Rioters to stop blaming the community over this situation. If you sit and think about the way company PR is set up at Riot and don't hold some communism levels of faith in humanity, then it's quite clear (at least in my opinion) that there was no way else things would have ended up,  except like this. It may have taken longer, or shorter, but eventually we would have ended up like this. It is not the community's fault, to blame the community is to blame human nature. Riot needs to revamp how they handle PR, or it is my solemnly held opinion they will not last another 4 years. This isn't meant to be mean btw, this is just me looking at the facts available to me.

P.S. (less chill here, mostly me venting on the stupidity of the situation): That comment, while certainly aggressive, is no where near bad enough to justify not responding to on that basis alone (which you avoided that pitfall, I applaud you good sir or madame). If you think that is bad, work some retail.  As a person, yeah, ignore it; but right now, you represent a company, there are different levels of acceptability for each. A company is expected to reply to a concern like that somewhere, and promptly. They can't just ignore these types of concerns without hurting themselves, it's basic business knowledge, why do you think customers abuse it so much in retail stores?

I've been chat restricted and had my honor reset for calling someone a noob, yet Riot employees get to tell the playerbase to kill themselves... and it's fine. Feels pretty bad to have my honor reset, even more so because I suffer from anxiety... which essentially makes my honor getting reset a mental health issue. Riot employees didn't care one bit.

The loading screen says you won't get punished for leaving, if you only have one bad game. But you can have a bad game due to things like depression or anxiety and Riot WILL punish you. And when you tell people who suffer from depression to kill themselves, you're not helping in any way.

It totally is unfair that the playerbase is fed all this stuff about what is and isn't toxic, yet Riot employees aren't leading by example at all. Nor are Riot employees being held to the same standard that's being forced on the playerbase.
The guy has just stated that this behaviour is why you don't see more Rioters posting, and the first thing you do is more of it. Do you actually not want Riot to interact with the community at all?

That second paragraph shows you don't understand systemic sexism (or discrimination in general).

The problem is not that Riot hired a few bad apples that are sexist pigs. The problem instead is that our modern society is fundamentally sexist, and that we all have biases and prejudice against women, and Riot company culture exacerbates those biases.

People are NOT *consciously* sexist and harassing women and thinking men are superior, at least most of them. But we ALL participate in hurtful behavior created by unconscious biases. And firing all the current male Rioters and replacing them would solve nothing.

When people say "there is a sexism problem at Riot (and in the game industry in general)", this is not an attack against individual men, it's an attack against the toxic society we all live in. And if you feel the initiative at Pax is an attack against male players, you haven't understood the problem.

EDIT: also, what are you referencing in that first paragraph about Rioter telling others to kill themselves?

As for solutions, I think the following may assist:

1.) Make muting more visible: Right now I have to hold down tab and click a tiny button to mute someone, and admittedly in the heat of things you may forget muting even exists.  How about this:
            a.) As soon as you enter the game you receive an obtrusive and very visible tooltip warning against toxicity and reminding players to mute toxic individuals.
            b.) At key trigger moments (such as a player first death) issue the team/player an unobtrusive reminder to mute toxicity.

2.) Reward positive behavior: Make no mistake capitalism only works because the rewards for conformity are exceedingly handsome, but in the end, everyone is just working in their self-interests. LOL is no different. Honor rewards are a fantastic idea but it could use some tweaking. The rewards are so far apart, progression is invisible, and the rewards have little differentiation from loot boxes/missions. Because of this, honor progression is very passive (it comes when it comes) and very few people actively pursue honor. 

If the rewards for honor allowed for a type of "farm", for example, if honor was the most efficient way of farming an important resource like orange essence (2 OE/honor....1 free skin/50 positive games), you would see players actively pursuing honor. Gradually, this would result in a mindset shift in the player base, because the benefits of being respectful simply outweigh the benefits of venting.

I'd humbly suggest that the effort to provide privacy to punished players by limiting feedback to those who report them is backfiring on you guys. I'm sure there might be legal or ethical issues involved that I haven't fully considered, but the current state of the report system has the average player feeling very little confidence that their reports matter. This leads to lots of misinformation: The assumption that we need to rally more reports against a player to have action taken against them, or that lack of feedback necessarily means that the reported player was not punished, or that certain clearly transgressive behaviors are simply ignored by Riot. 

Honest question: What would be the downside of having a report dashboard, where we can actually see which of our reports resulted in action, were dismissed, have an ongoing review, etc.?

I think a complete dashboard would be somewhat dangerous. If you have the specific outcomes of every single report you filed you might be able to analyse the way reports are reviewed

That said, I think the bigger reason is that the actual outcomes of a report are much more complex than that. The automatic review might easily consider the report valid, but still not take an actual action because it was a first-time occurrence of very mild toxicity. Likewise the system might suggest that a single somewhat passive aggressive remark has lead to an action, when it was just the final straw.

The only way to work around that is by changing the concept of actions to "verdicts" of some kind, that display how much toxicity the system detected.
But that will without a doubt create problems of its own: Since the scale of actions is now very nuanced, the chance of the reporter agreeing 100% with the verdict is very slim. As a result people will hardly ever experience those verdicts as "good", while every major disagreement with a verdict will be a very memorable bad impression. Negativity bias will do the rest and people will feel even **worse** about the system, even if it's objectively (and in the bigger picture) functioning very well.

I still believe the best idea would be that once a month upon login you are given the overall stats of how many people have been punished due to your reports, at the time of the report or later because of repeated toxicity. I wouldn't even include the total amount of reports, in order to make it clear that the purpose of the message isn't to give you a "score" or judge your report validity, but simply to tell you how much absolute impact your reports had on the community.
Maybe, and really just maybe, I'd also include the amount of people that were punished exclusively because of your report (because nobody else reported them in that game) so can see that you've made a difference.
